title: Alert
summary: An alert displays important messages, feedback, or time-sensitive information.
preamble: An alert is a message used to inform the user about the state of a system, page, or function. Icons and color indicate the type and urgency of the information within the message.
anatomy-overview: Alert consists of a card with an icon, a message text, optional action button, and optional close button. The layout is responsive and adapts based on the size of the Alert.

overview.title: Variants
overview.section-content: Supports five variants (\`information\`, `notice`, `positive`, `warning`, `negative`), each with specific icons and color schemes to convey different types of messages.

columns.title: Information
columns.content: Shares non-urgent updates, like new features or tips, with a brief message and optional next steps.

columns.title: Notice
columns.content: Conveys general announcements or non-critical updates, like service changes, with a short description and optional guidance.

columns.title: Positive
columns.content: Confirms successful actions, like form submissions, with a success message, optional next steps, and possible brand reinforcement.

columns.title: Warning
columns.content: Highlights non-critical issues, like upcoming deadlines, with a concise issue summary, optional duration estimate, and suggested actions.

columns.title: Negative
columns.content: Communicates critical issues or errors, like system outages, with a clear problem description, optional apology for system issues, and resolution guidance.

overview.title: Action button
overview.section-content: The Alert supports an optional action button with customizable text to trigger relevant actions.

overview.title: Dismissibility
overview.section-content:
The Alert can be configured as `dismissible` in order to show a close button in the upper right corner. This also enabled closing the Alert by pressing the Escape key.

#### Auto-dismiss

The Alert can also be set up to use an auto-dismiss timer. In this configuration, a timer progress bar will be shown at the bottom of the Alert, and the Alert will close once the timer reaches the end.

overview.title: Guidelines
overview.section-content:
Select the appropriate variant to match the message’s intent, such as using positive for success messages or negative for errors. Also ensure a meaningful label property is set to describe the alert’s purpose for accessibility. A label should alwys be set when using Alert.

Choose the role property carefully, using alert for critical messages and status for informational updates, to align with ARIA best practices.

For toast-like messages, like save confirmations and other non-critical messages, auto-dismiss can be used to avoid interrupting user workflows.

columns.title: Do
columns.content:
*   Use concise, clear message text to ensure quick comprehension.
    
*   Enable `dismissible` for alerts, unless you need them to stay on screen permanently.

columns.title: Dont
columns.content:
*   Don’t use overly long message text.
    
*   Avoid using `alert` role for non-critical messages; use `status` instead to reduce urgency.
    
*   Don’t set a timeout for critical alerts that require user acknowledgment.
    
*   Never omit the label property, as it’s essential for screen reader users.
    
*   Don’t use vague `button-label` text like “Click Here”; be specific about the action.
